source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk1
evidence_span: Long-term static autoclave corrosion tests were conducted on Zircaloy-4 tube specimens in water at 633 K
process_step: annealing parameter range 10^-17 to 10^-19 h with Q/R = 40000 K, fabrication history variation of early and late beta-quenching steps, and final heat treatment variation from several levels of stress-relief-anneal to a recrystallization anneal
conditions: water at 633 K, exposure times up to 1160 days
corrosion_data: weight gain data show transitions to an accelerated corrosion rate that became apparent at exposure times greater than 300 days

extra_properties.corrosion_rate_acceleration: associated with hydride precipitation and fracture

evidence_span: Specimen No. 1: EPRI Std., Sn% 1.55, Fe% 0.20, Cr% 0.11, Si 83 ppm, C 140 ppm, Integrated Annealing Parameter 1 × 10 exp-17 ha, Final Heat Treatment SRA
conditions: 633 K deionized water, pH 6.0-6.5, up to 1160 days

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk7
evidence_span: Mechanical property data on zirconium hydride [32] show that below 700 K (427°C) zirconium hydride is a brittle material and above this temperature it exhibits increasing ductility with increasing temperature. These high temperature tensile tests on hydrided zirconium containing 40 to 50.6 atomic percent hydrogen

extra_properties.ductility: brittle below 700 K, increasing ductility above 700 K

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk8
evidence_span: The fine second-phase particles in the Specimen 3 material (which includes a late betaquench step) provide a large number of closely spaced nucleation sites [3436] for hydride precipitates. The increased number density of the hydride precipitates is believed to be responsible for the strong corrosion rate enhancement exhibited by this material.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk8
evidence_span: The occasional higher corrosion rates of RXA cladding compared to the SRA cladding may be related to the higher $f _ { N }$ for RXA cladding.
corrosion_data: occasional higher corrosion rates for RXA

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk8
evidence_span: In a "banded" hydride structure, the hydride free regions will slow down the progress of the oxidation front into the metal and thereby slow the acceleration of the corrosion process.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk8
evidence_span: Long-term autoclave tests in water at $6 3 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ and steam at $6 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$ are being evaluated in several laboratories regarding their correlation with the corrosion performance in PWRs.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk8
evidence_span: Increasing the test temperature to $6 7 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ does not necessarily produce more aggressive corrosion conditions than those at $6 3 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ . Compared to the test at $6 3 3 ~ \mathrm { K }$ , a higher corrosion rate (associated with the higher oxygen diffusion rate) and higher hydrogen absorption fraction at $6 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$ is countered to some extent by the higher hydrogen solubility and greater hydride ductility at $6 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk9
evidence_span: For extended burnup applications in PWRs, the cladding corrosion rate late in life is important...
corrosion_data: corrosion rate acceleration after long exposures

extra_properties.grain_structure: RXA (recrystallized annealed) vs SRA (stress relieved annealed)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_035_chunk9
evidence_span: The short transition time for Specimen 3 (141 days)...
corrosion_data: short transition time (141 days) indicating corrosion acceleration
